section.p:

section.p: Finally, we'll review an application of using vertical and horizontal translations to quickly perform a familiar task: Finding the equation of a line

statement.p: The linear function f(x) = 4x will graph as a line with slope 4, passing through the origin (0,0).
Now, using translations, it would be easy to write the equations of similar lines.
For example:
The line with slope 4, passing through the point (7,15), may be thought of as the result of shifting f(x) to the right by 7 units, and up by 15 units.
[In this case, we are focusing our attention on moving the old point (0,0) to the new point (7,15).]
What would be the equation of this new line?
Answer:

hint.p: Since f(x) has the point (0,0), think about shifting that point to (7,15). Remember that adding to the input will move the graph to the left, and subtracting from the input will move the graph to the right.

solution.p: Without doing any simplification to the formula, the line would be: y \amp= f(x-7) + 15 \amp= 4(x-7) + 15

statement.p: The equation of a line with slope m, passing through the origin, is just: y = mx
If we wanted to change this line so it had the same slope but passed through the point (a,b), what would be the equation?
Answer:
This is a very useful formula for writing the equation of a line if you know the slope and any single point on its graph. This formula is called the Point-Slope formula for a line.

solution.p: The equation is y = m(x-a) + b no matter the sign (+ or -) on the values a and b.

section.title: Horizontal Stretches/Compressions
section.p: We have already seen that the graph of a function may be stretched or compressed vertically by multiplying the output of the function by a constant number a.

li.p: If a>1, then graphing y = af(x) would be the result of stretching y = f(x) vertically, away from the xaxis. All of the y values on the graph of f(x) would be multiplied by this number a, so they would now be larger in magnitude (either positive or negative). Thus, the points would be stretched farther away from the xaxis.

If 0<a<1, then the graph of y = af(x) would be like compressing the graph of y = f(x) vertically, toward the xaxis. All of the y values on the graph of f(x) would be multiplied by the number a, so they would become smaller in magnitude. Thus, the points would be compressed toward the xaxis.

section.p: Finally, we know that adding or subtracting a number from the input of a function will shift the graph either left or right.

paragraphs.title: Horizontal Stretches and Compressions

section.p: It may have surprised you to see that multiplying the input of a function by a number larger than 1 actually made the graph compress horizontally.
Why did this happen? Let's crunch some numbers for a function and one of its transformations.

statement.p: The table below shows some values for the function f(x) and its transformation f(2x).
Complete the values for the transformation f(2x).

answer.p: For any value of the input x, evaluating f(2x) means you're looking at the output of f farther down the table, where the input is 2x.
So, when x = 2, the output of f(2x) is the same as f(4) = 23.

The completed table looks like:
x f(x) f(2x)
1 8 13
2 13 23
3 18 33
4 23 43
5 28 53
6 33 63
[The function f is linear, and its pattern can be used to determine values of the table.]

section.p: Notice that the output values for f(x), which occur later in the table, now happen earlier for the transformation f(2x). This makes sense graphically, as the points at certain heights now occur earlier, at smaller xvalues for f(2x).

note.p: It is useful to realize that a transformation like f(0.25x) may be written as: f\left(\frac{x}{4}\right) Any transformation of the type f(ax) may be rewritten as f\left(\dfrac{x}{\sfrac{1}{a}}\right), where one of the numbers, a or \frac{1}{a}, is greater than 1.
Therefore, another way to remember what this type of transformation does is the following.

If you rewrite the transformation so that a>1, then:
f(ax)
Compresses the graph of f by a factor of a
Multiplying the input variable by a number greater than 1 will compress the graph.
Example: f(3x) is only 1/3 as wide as f(x).
f\big(\frac{x}{a}\big)
Stretches the graph of f by a factor of a
Example? f\left(\frac{x}{4}\right) is 4 times as wide as f(x).

section.p: Often, we will want to horizontally stretch or compress a function by a certain factor. Or, if we already have a transformed function's graph, we may need to determine what the stretching/compressing factor was.

statement.p: The graph at left shows y = f(x). This graph was horizontally stretched to make the graph y = f(ax) at right.
The objective is to find what value of a caused the horizontal stretch to the graph of f.

li.p: Since this transformation stretches points away from the xaxis, fix your attention on the point (2, 0) on the graph of f.
Its corresponding point (5, 0) on the graph of g has been stretched by what factor away from the xaxis? That is, how many times larger is the xvalue of the stretched point?
Using the idea from Note, determine the value of a if the stretched graph is f\left(\frac{x}{a}\right).

solution.p: The points on g(x) are \frac{5}{2}=2.5 times as far from the xaxis as those on the graph of f(x).

Since the graph was stretched, then we know that the transformation is f\left(\frac{x}{a}\right) where a = 2.5. So, the transformation could be written as either: y = f\left(\frac{x}{2.5}\right) Or y = f\left(0.4x\right)
